One of the first efforts to target the ACE2 receptors was documented by Liu et al. Using a novel epitope assembling assay, Liu et al. identified linear B-cell immuno-cross-reactive epitopes of SARS-CoV S protein by synthesizing 22 longer peptides. Five of these peptides showed serologically highly cross-reactivity in all tested SARS patients sera. Among them, peptide S 471-503 could significantly block the binding of RBD to ACE2. S 471-503, derived from the S1 fragment ( Figure 7 and Table 2 ) could target ACE2, and showed antiviral activity against SARS-CoV infection in vitro, with an EC 50 value of 41.6 Î¼M, providing an important basis to explore the antiviral potential of S 471-503 against SARS-CoV-2.
